natural problem: How many 9-step paths are there from $E$ to $G$?[asy]size(4cm,4cm);int w=6;int h=5;int i;for (i=0; i<h; ++i){draw((0,i) -- (w-1,i));}for (i=0; i<w; ++i){draw((i, 0)--(i,h-1));}label("$G$", (w-1,0), SE);label("$E$", (0,h-1), NW);[/asy]
natural solution: There are 5 steps to the right, and 4 steps down. These 9 steps can be made in any order, so the answer is $\dbinom{9}{4} = \dfrac{9 \times 8 \times 7 \times 6}{4 \times 3 \times 2 \times 1} = \boxed{126}$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes E G :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "E 0 = 0"
and h1 : "G 0 = 0"
and h2 : "\<forall>n. E (Suc n) = E n + 1 \<and> G (Suc n) = G n + 1"
and h3 : "\<forall>n. n \<le> 9 \<longrightarrow> (\<exists>k. E n = k \<and> G n = k + 4)"
shows  "card {n. n \<le> 9 \<and> (\<exists>k. E n = k \<and> G n = k + 4)} = 126"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many 9-step paths are there from $E$ to $G$?[asy]size(4cm,4cm);int w=6;int h=5;int i;for (i=0; i<h; ++i){draw((0,i) -- (w-1,i));}for (i=0; i<w; ++i){draw((i, 0)--(i,h-1));}label("$G$", (w-1,0), SE);label("$E$", (0,h-1), NW);[/asy] The final Answer is 126
 ### Proof
 There are 5 steps to the right, and 4 steps down. These 9 steps can be made in any order, so the answer is $\dbinom{9}{4} = \dfrac{9 \times 8 \times 7 \times 6}{4 \times 3 \times 2 \times 1} = \boxed{126}$.
 *)

fixes E G :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "E 0 = 0"
and h1 : "G 0 = 0"
and h2 : "\<forall>n. E (Suc n) = E n + 1 \<and> G (Suc n) = G n + 1"
and h3 : "\<forall>n. n \<le> 9 \<longrightarrow> (\<exists>k. E n = k \<and> G n = k + 4)"
shows  "card {n. n \<le> 9 \<and> (\<exists>k. E n = k \<and> G n = k + 4)} = 126"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Define two sequences $E$ and $G$ such that $E(0) = G(0) = 0$, $E(n+1) = E(n) + 1$, and $G(n+1) = G(n) + 1$ for all non-negative integers $n$. Find the number of elements $n \leq 9$ for which there exists an integer $k$ such that $E(n) = k$ and $G(n) = k + 4$. The final answer is 126.
